Detailed Description

Interface and factory for dat-file writing.

This class is a factory for dat-file writers. Furthermore it is the interface used by said writers. Use this class if you want to write ADTF 2 compatible dat files.

Definition at line 27 of file adtf_filewriter_intf.h.

Member Function Documentation

void *  pFactory 
)
static

Add an additional class and its classfactory to the writer, e.g.

in order to add more known sample types Call before the first call to create!!!

Parameters
strID[in] Identifier of class
pFactory[in] pointer to factory that creates the class
Return values
ERR_NOERRORif all went well
ERR_POINTERif strId or pFactory was NULL
ERR_UNEXPECTEDif IADTFFileWriter::Create() has been called before

virtual tResult Close ( )
pure virtual

Closes the ADTF file.

The close method closes the dat file. If there is a media description set for any stream this also writes the media description file for the DAT. Don't forget to call Release.

Return values
ERR_NOERRORif all went well
ERR_UNEXPECTEDif no file was open

static

Creates a dat file writer.

The function creates a dat file writer to create and populate a new dat-file.

Return values

NULLif something went wrong.
virtual tResult CreateStream ( const tChar *  strName,
tUInt16 &  ui16StreamId,
tUInt32  ui32MajorType,
tUInt32  ui32SubType,
const tChar *  strMediaType = STREAMING_MEDIA_TYPE_GENERIC,
const tChar *  strSampleType = STREAMING_SAMPLE_TYPE_GENERIC,
void *  pFormatData = NULL,
const void *  pAdditionalData = NULL,
tInt  nAdditionalDataSize = 0 
)
pure virtual

This method creates a named stream inside the dat file.

It returns a stream handle which can be used to write to this stream using IADTFFileWriter::Write()

Parameters
strName[in] name of stream, must be unique inside of file
ui16StreamId[out] id of created stream. Invalid if return value is not equal to ERR_NOERROR
ui32MajorType[in]Major media type identificator of this stream
ui32SubType[in]sub media type identificator of this stream
strMediaType[in] string that identifies the mediatype used. For a list of default mediatypes see adtf_mediatypes.h
strSampleType[in] string specifying the type of mediasmaple to use For a list of default mediatsampleypes see adtf_mediatypes.h
pFormatData[in] format data for audio or video pins. Use tAudioFormat or tVideoFormat here.
pAdditionalData[in] Pointer to additional data for the MediaType.
nAdditionalDataSize[in] The Size of the additional data.
Remarks
Most filters use the default media type and sample type but set a specific major and sub type. See the canwriter example, since can data uses a special media sample
Return values
ERR_NOERRORif all went well
ERR_INVALID_ARGif strName,strMediaType or strSampleType was empty
ERR_POINTERif strName, strMediaType or strSampleType was NULL
ERR_UNEXPECTEDif a stream with this name already exists
ERR_FAILEDif either the sampletype or the mediatype could not be resolved.
Remarks
If you are using non-standard types, load the appropiate class factories first.
virtual tInt GetExtensionCount ( )
pure virtual

Gets the extension count.

This function retrieves the number of extensions the dat file contains.

Note
your written dat-file will contain a few more extensions than this function returns since straminfos are stored as extension, too, at the time the file is closed
Returns
Returns the number of extensions.

virtual tResult Open ( const tChar *  strFileName,
tUInt32  ui32Flags = 0 
)
pure virtual

Opens the ADTF file.

Parameters
strFileName[in] The Filename as null terminated string (relative or absolute path)
ui32Flags[in] Flags which describe the writing behavior (e.g. synchronous or asynchronous). See adtfstreaming::tOpenMode to get all available flags.
Return values
ERR_NOERRORif all went well.
ERR_POINTERif strFileName is NULL
ERR_INVALID_ARGinternal error
ERR_MEMORYif a problem occurred while reserving memory for index table
Remarks
The adtf writer can open the dat file only in writing access mode.

Return values

virtual tResult SetMediaDescription ( const tChar *  strShortDescription,
const tChar *  strLongDescription,
const tDateTime *  pDateTime = NULL 
)
pure virtual

This function sets the media description of the DAT File.

Parameters
strShortDescription[in] short description of DAT File content. May be NULL.
strLongDescription[in] short description of DAT File content May be NULL.
pDateTime[in] date and time of DAT File creation. May be NULL.
Note
If either strShortDescription or strLongDescription is NULL, the Description of the file is not modified.
The short description must not contain the EOL (end of line) character, because EOL is used as separator between the short and long description. ERR_UNEXPECTED is returned if the short description contains the EOL character.
The length of the short description is limited to 128 characters. The text after the 128th character will be cut.
If pDateTime is NULL, the creation dat and time of the file are not modified.
call this after successfully calling Open.
Return values
ERR_NOERRORif all went well.
ERR_UNEXPECTEDif call on non open file
virtual tResult SetStreamMediaDescription ( tUInt16  ui16StreamId,
const tChar *  strMediaDescription 
)
pure virtual

This function sets the media description.

Parameters
ui16StreamId[in] id to look up.
strMediaDescription[in] media description to connect with the stream
Return values
Standarderror result code
ERR_UNEXPECTEDmedia type does not support media description or invalid XML tag
ERR_INVALID_ARGno description for this stream available
ERR_POINTERNull-pointer committed
ERR_NOT_INITIALISEDDDLImporter was not initialized yet
ERR_UNKNOWN_FORMATExpected XML hierarchy not found
ERR_NO_CLASSCross reference not resolvable (e.g. refUnit)
ERR_UNKNOWNCross reference has not been resolved
ERR_INVALID_VERSIONIncompatible DDL descriptions detected (not the same DDL version)
ERR_NOT_FOUNDAt least one mandatory element (e.g. header) was not found
virtual tResult Write ( tUInt16  ui16StreamId,
const void *  pvData,
tInt64  i64DataSize,
tTimeStamp  tmTimeStampData,
tUInt16  ui16FlagsDataType = cADTFDataBlock::DTF_DATA,
tTimeStamp  tmFileTimeStamp = -1,
tUInt32  ui32FlagsInternal = 0 
)
pure virtual

This method writes the specified data to a dat file.

Parameters
ui16StreamId[in] id of stream to write to. Stream must have been created previously using IADTFFileWriter::CreateStream
pvData[in] pointer to data to write
i64DataSize[in] size of data in byte (mind the real maximum of data size depends on compiler and system architecture using)
tmTimeStampData[in] timestamp used both for media sample as for location in dat file
ui16FlagsDataType[in] data type flag of written data
tmFileTimeStamp[in] timestamp of chunk inside of dat-file. If -1, timestamp is calculated as rising time
ui32FlagsInternal[in] Sample flags
See also
ADTF MediaSample Flags Internals
Note
It is legal to set pvData to NULL if and only if u32DataSize is 0. This creates empty media samples with a timestamp.
Return values
ERR_NOERRORif all went well
ERR_POINTERif pData is NULL and u32DataSize is greater than 0
ERR_INVALID_ARGif nStreamId is 0
ERR_UNKNOWNif nStreamId does not belong to a known stream
ERR_UNEXPECTEDif no datfile created
ERR_OUT_OF_SYNCif nFileTimeStamp is specified and is less than the last file time stamp. This is a sanity check: time does not flow backwards
virtual tResult Write ( cADTFDataBlock *  pBlock)
pure virtual

This method writes the specified data to a dat file.

Parameters
pBlock[in] reference to the block to write
Note
Additional information (like the file timestamp, flags, etc.) will be taken from the given data block pBlock.
Return values
ERR_NOERRORif all went well
ERR_POINTERif pData is NULL and u32DataSize is greater than 0
ERR_INVALID_ARGif nStreamId is 0
ERR_UNKNOWNif nStreamId does not belong to a known stream
ERR_UNEXPECTEDif no datfile created
ERR_OUT_OF_SYNCif nFileTimeStamp is specified and is less than the last file time stamp. This is a sanity check: time does not flow backwards
